project.name: Kiwi.js
project.description: Kiwi.js is a Javascript/Typescript library for creating HTML5 games.

Tweens.name: Tweens
Tweens.description: The section of Kiwi which holds the scripts that manage Tween's in Kiwi. The scripts in this section are based on Tween.js by sole and have been converted to TypeScript and integrated into Kiwi. https://github.com/sole/tween.js

Easing.name: Easing
Easing.description: Contains various methods that can be used when you are wanting to ease a Tween.

Animations.name: Animations
Animations.description: Is the namespace in which all code that is used to create/provide an animation of various sorts are stored. These could range from animations that change the cell of a SpriteSheet that is displayed every few seconds (Animation/Sequence), to animations that change a numeric value on a object over a period time (Tweens).

Kiwi.name: Kiwi
Kiwi.description:
Module - Kiwi (Core)
The top level namespace in which all core classes and modules are defined.

Components.name: Components
Components.description: Component's are a snipnets of code which are designed to provide extra functionality to various objects that contain a ComponentManager. Objects do not have to have Components in order to preform their main function, but are instead provided to make common task's that you may want to do with those Objects a bit easier. For example: Some times you would like to easily listen for when a GameObject has been 'clicked'. So you can attach a 'InputComponent' to a GameObject (Sprites have them by default) which will then do hit-detector code for you. All you have to do is Subscribe to the events on the InputComponent.

Files.name: Files
Files.description: Holds a reference to all of the data Files (json, xml, e.t.c) that are accessible on the State that this DataLibrary is on.

GameObjects.name: GameObjects
GameObjects.description: The GameObject namespace holds classes which are designed to be added to a State (either directly, or as an ancestor of a Group) and are the Objects that are used when wanting to render anything visual onto the current State. Each GameObject is a representation of a particular item in a game and as such has information that corresponds to that item (like where they are in the 'GameWorld', the scale of the GameObject, who their parent is, e.t.c). For Example: If you wanted to have a massive background image then you can use the StaticImage GameObject, as that is a relatively light-weight object). Or if you had Player with an Animation, which user's could interactive with, then you would use a Sprite, which is more robust.

Tilemap.name: Tilemap
Tilemap.description:
A TileMap handles the creation of TileMapLayers and the TileTypes that they use.
Since a TileMap isn't a Entity itself you cannot add it to the Stage inorder to render that it manages, 
Instead you have to add each layer lies within it. This way you can have other GameObjects behind/in-front of layers.

Geom.name: Geom
Geom.description: Contains common classes whose applications deal with geometry or the collision of geometric shapes.

HUD.name: HUD
HUD.description:
The HUD (Heads Up Display) is a section that handles the displayment of information that you always want visible to user. 
This section is managed differently to normal GameObjects, where the difference being that HUD items aren't added to a Canvas but are DOM elements instead. Since they DOM elements you can style these elements using a CSS sheet if you wish.

HUDComponents.name: HUDComponents
HUDComponents.description: HUDComponents are a space where components that are specific to HUDWidgets are kept. This are seperated from the normal Components section as the implementation of these are unique and only make sense when implemented on HUDWidgets, otherwise the concepts behind these are the same as normal Components.

Widget.name: Widget
Widget.description:
HUD Widgets are objects that are generally placed on to a HUD Display for displaying and managing information that the user would always need to see.
An example of such information would be: the Health remaining, amount of ammo left, time they have left, e.t.c.
And each one of those examples would have its own widget.

Input.name: Input
Input.description: Section that contains the code related to handling user interaction with a game.

Renderers.name: Renderers
Renderers.description: Contains the classes which are related to the rendering of GameObjects.

Shaders.name: Shaders
Shaders.description:
GLSL ES Shaders are used for WebGL rendering.
ShaderPair objects encapsulate GLSL ES vertex and fragment shader programs. 
  ShaderPairs contain the GLSL code, provide an interface to uniforms and attributes, and have the ability to link and compile the shaders.
The ShaderManager keeps track of each ShaderPair, and controls which one is bound for use at any particular time.
  Only the ShaderManager can create ShaderPairs. When a renderer (see note on renderes below) requests a ShaderPair the ShaderManager will either
      1) Return a reference to an already instantiated ShaderPair, and set the GL state to use the shader program or
      2) Return a reference to a new ShaderPair, which will be linked and compiled and bound for use.
  All ShaderPairs must be housed as properties of the Kiwi.Shaders object. 

Kiwi.Renderer objects use a ShaderPair to draw.
  They must request a ShaderPair from the ShaderManager.
  Many renderers may use the same ShaderPair.
  Some renderers may at different times use multiple ShaderPairs (only one is possible at any given time)

Sound.name: Sound
Sound.description: The namespace that holds all of the assets and functionality when dealing with Audio.

Textures.name: Textures
Textures.description: Contains Objects that are used when dealing specifically with Textures/Images. Majority of these classes are for Internal Kiwi use.

Time.name: Time
Time.description: Contains ways of tracking time within a game or application. Each game will have a ClockManager, MasterClock and a single Clock automatically generated for them upon game creation.

Utils.name: Utils
Utils.description: Utils is a space that holds a wide varity of useful methods.

Kiwi.Animations.Tween.name: Kiwi.Animations.Tween
Kiwi.Animations.Tween.description:
Manages the tweening of properties/values on a single object. A Tween is the animation of a number between an initially value to and final value (that you specify). 
Note: When using a Tween you need to make sure that the Tween has been added to a TweenManager. You can either do this by creating the Tween via the Manager or alternatively using the 'add' method on the TweenManager. Otherwise the tween will not work.

Based on tween.js by sole. Converted to TypeScript and integrated into Kiwi.
https://github.com/sole/tween.js

params.name: object
params.description: The object that this tween is taking affect on.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this tween is for.

Kiwi.Animations.Tween.author: egraether / http://egraether.com/

Kiwi.Animations.Tweens.TweenManager.name: Kiwi.Animations.Tweens.TweenManager
Kiwi.Animations.Tweens.TweenManager.description:
The TweenManager is automatically created on every game. This class is responsible for the creation and management of tweens for the game.
 
Based on tween.js by sole. Converted to TypeScript and integrated into Kiwi.
https://github.com/sole/tween.js
Kiwi.Animations.Tweens.TweenManager.author: egraether / http://egraether.com/

Kiwi.Animations.Animation.name: Kiwi.Animations.Animation
Kiwi.Animations.Animation.description:
An Animation contains information about a single animation that is held on a AnimationManager. 
The information that is held is unique to this individual animation and will initially be the same as a Sequence,
but if you do ever modify the information held in this Animation the corresponding Sequence will not be updated.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of this anim.

params.name: sequences
params.description: The sequence that this anim will be using to animate.

params.name: clock
params.description: A game clock that this anim will be using to keep record of the time between frames.

params.name: parent
params.description: The animation manager that this animation belongs to.

Kiwi.Animations.Sequence.name: Kiwi.Animations.Sequence
Kiwi.Animations.Sequence.description:
A Sequence is a series of cells that are held on a SpriteSheet/TextureAtlas.
Sequences are generally used with the AnimationManager/Animation sections as a way to initially create Animations on GameObjects that use the same TextureAtlas.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of this sequence. This is not unique.

params.name: cells
params.description: The cells that are in this animation.

params.name: speed
params.description: The time an animation should spend on each frame.

params.name: loop
params.description: If the sequence should play again if it was animating and the animation reaches the last frame.

Kiwi.Components.AnimationManager.name: Kiwi.Components.AnimationManager
Kiwi.Components.AnimationManager.description:
The AnimationManager is used to handle the creation and use of spritesheet Animations on a GameObject based on the TextureAtlas it has. 
If the When the AnimationManager is instantiated it will loop through all of the Sequences on the TextureAtlas of the GameObject being used and will create a new Animation for each one.
Now when you create a new Animation that animation will automatically be added as a new Sequence to the corresponding Texture. 
This way you don't need to create new Animations for a each Sprite that use's the same Texture.

params.name: entity
params.description: The entity that this animation component belongs to.

params.name: inheritSequences
params.description: If a new Animation should be created for each Sequence on the Entities TextureAtlas it is a part of or not.

Kiwi.Components.ArcadePhysics.name: Kiwi.Components.ArcadePhysics
Kiwi.Components.ArcadePhysics.description:
Arcade Physics is an Optional Component that can be used when you are wanting to do basic physics collisions. 
These have been ported from Flixel, so most function operate identically to the original flixel functions, though some
have been split into multiple functions. Generally where functions originally accepted
either groups or gameobjects within the same argument, the ported functions one or the other.
http://www.flixel.org/
http://www.adamatomic.com/

params.name: entity
params.description: The Entity that this ArcadePhysics should be used on.

params.name: box
params.description: The box component that holds the hitbox that should be used when resolving and calculating collisions.

Kiwi.Components.ArcadePhysics.author: Adam 'Atomic' Saltsman, Flixel

Kiwi.Components.Box.name: Kiwi.Components.Box
Kiwi.Components.Box.description:
The Box Component is used to handle the various 'bounds' that each GameObject has. 
There are two main different types of bounds (Bounds and Hitbox) with each one having three variants (each one is a rectangle) depending on what you are wanting:

RawBounds: The bounding box of the GameObject before rotation/scale.

RawHitbox: The hitbox of the GameObject before rotation/scale. This can be modified to be different than the normal bounds but if not specified it will be the same as the raw bounds.

Bounds: The bounding box of the GameObject after rotation/scale.

Hitbox: The hitbox of the GameObject after rotation/scale. If you modified the raw hitbox then this one will be modified as well, otherwise it will be the same as the normal bounds.

WorldBounds: The bounding box of the Entity using its world coordinates and after rotation/scale.

WorldHitbox: The hitbox of the Entity using its world coordinates and after rotation/scale.

params.name: parent
params.description: The entity that this box belongs to.

params.name: x
params.description: Its position on the x axis

params.name: y
params.description: Its position on the y axis

params.name: width
params.description: The width of the box.

params.name: height
params.description: The height of the box.

Kiwi.Components.Input.name: Kiwi.Components.Input
Kiwi.Components.Input.description:
The Input Component is used on GameObjects in which the user may interactive with via a Mouse or Touch 
and as such this class contains useful methods and callbacks you can subscribe to. 
By default the Input component is disabled (this is because when enabled the input component can be process intensive) 
but you can enabled it yourself (which is recommened) BUT in case you forget the input component will automagically 
be enabled once you access a Signal on this class.

params.name: owner
params.description: The Object that this Component is on. Generally this will be a Entity.

params.name: box
params.description: The box which contains the worldHitbox that is to be used for the event firing.

params.name: enabled
params.description: If this input component should be enabled or not.

Kiwi.Components.Sound.name: Kiwi.Components.Sound
Kiwi.Components.Sound.description:
The Sound Component is a class to assist with the creation and management of multiple pieces of audio that may exist on a single Entity. 
This class is NOT needed when dealing with audio but is instead can be used to assist in dealing with audio.

params.name: parent
params.description: Who the owner of the sound component is.

Kiwi.Camera.name: Kiwi.Camera
Kiwi.Camera.description: A Camera is used to render a particular section of the game world on the stage. Each Camera has a coordinates which are held in the transform property, and a width/height. Note: This class should never be directly instantiated but instead should be made through a CameraManager's 'create' method.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this camera belongs to.

params.name: id
params.description: A unique ID for this camera

params.name: name
params.description: The name this camera goes by

params.name: x
params.description: The x coordinate of the camera

params.name: y
params.description: The y coordinate of the camera

params.name: width
params.description: The width of the camera

params.name: height
params.description: The cameras height

Kiwi.CameraManager.name: Kiwi.CameraManager
Kiwi.CameraManager.description:
Used to handle the creation and management of Cameras on a Game. Each Game will always have created for it a CameraManager and a default Camera on the manager. 
Games currently only usupport the use of a single camera, the default camera. Much of this class has been written with future multiple camera support in mind.

Kiwi.Component.name: Kiwi.Component
Kiwi.Component.description:
The base class that all components extend from. It contains all of the common functionality that is required of every Component.
Any object

params.name: owner
params.description: The object that this component belongs to.

params.name: componentName
params.description: The name of this component.

Kiwi.ComponentManager.name: Kiwi.ComponentManager
Kiwi.ComponentManager.description:
The component manager is a class that is used to handle components that are active on a particular object. Any object
that has a component manager attached to it can use components.
If you want to check to see if a particular component is on an object you can ask the component manager, 
or when updating components you can tell the component manager to update and all of the components will update as well.

params.name: type
params.description: - The type of object that this component manager's owner is.

params.name: owner
params.description: - The owner of this component manager.

Kiwi.Entity.name: Kiwi.Entity
Kiwi.Entity.description:
An Entity is a base class for game objects to extend from and thus you should never directly instantiate this class.
Every entity requires that you pass to it the state that it belongs too, that way when you switch states the appropriate entitys can be deleted.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this entity belongs to. Used to generate the Unique ID and for garbage collection.

params.name: x
params.description: The entities position on the x axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The entities position on the y axis.

Kiwi.Game.name: Kiwi.Game
Kiwi.Game.description: The base class that is used when you create a new Game. Handles the initialisation of all of the various individual game managers and holds the RAF (RequestAnimationFrame object) which is used for the game loop.

params.name: domParent
params.description: The ID of a DOM element that the game should use as its 'container'. If you are targeting Cocoon then you don't need to worry about this and can leave it blank.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the game that is being created.

params.name: state
params.description: The state to load initially. This can either be the name of a state, but preferably this would be the state object itself.

params.name: options
params.description: Any special options for the game. E.g. Is DEBUG_ON or DEBUG_OFF, RENDERER_CANVAS or RENDERER_WEBGL, TARGET_BROWSER or TARGET_COCOON

Kiwi.Group.name: Kiwi.Group
Kiwi.Group.description:
The group class is central to creating the scene graph that contains all objects in a state. A group can contain entities or other groups, thereby enabling a nested tree scene graph.
The members of the Group's coordinates are also in relation to the Group that they were added to. So if you moved an entire Group, each member of that Group would also 'move'.

params.name: state
params.description: The State that this Group is a part of.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of this group.

Kiwi.IChild.name: Kiwi.IChild
Kiwi.IChild.description:
A IChild is an Interface (defined as a class as the documentation does not support Interfaces just yet),
which outlines the methods/properties that objects which are intended to be added as a child of a Stage or Group must have in order to work.
As Javascript does not use Interfaces, the IChild does not appear directly in the library. It describes common elements of Kiwi.Group and Kiwi.Entity.

Kiwi.PluginManager.name: Kiwi.PluginManager
Kiwi.PluginManager.description:
The plugin manager registers plugins, checks plugin dependencies, and calls designated functions on each registered plugin at boot time, and during the update loop if required.
Plugins are registered on the global Kiwi instance. Once a plugin in registered it is allocated a place on the Kiwi.Plugins name space.
Eg. FooPlugin will be accessible at Kiwi.Plugins.FooPlugin.
When a game instance is created, it can contain a list of required plugins in the configuration object. At this point the plugin manager will validate that the plugins
exist, and that dependencies are met (both Kiwi version and versions of other required plugins).
If the plugin has a "create" function, the plugin manager instance will call that function as part of the boot process. The create function may do anything, but usually it would create
an instance of an object. 
The plugin manager update function is called every update loop. If an object was created by the "create" function and it has an "update" function, that function will be called in turn.

params.name: game
params.description: The state that this entity belongs to. Used to generate the Unique ID and for garbage collection.

params.name: plugins
params.description: The entities position on the x axis.

Kiwi.Signal.name: Kiwi.Signal
Kiwi.Signal.description:
A TypeScript conversion of JS Signals by Miller Medeiros.
Released under the MIT license
http://millermedeiros.github.com/js-signals/
Kiwi.Signal.author: Miller Medeiros, JS Signals

Kiwi.SignalBinding.name: Kiwi.SignalBinding
Kiwi.SignalBinding.description:
An object that represents a binding between a Signal and a listener function.
- This is an internal constructor and shouldn't be called by regular users.
- inspired by Joa Ebert AS3 SignalBinding and Robert Penner's Slot classes. Released under the MIT license http://millermedeiros.github.com/js-signals/
Kiwi.SignalBinding.author: Miller Medeiros, JS Signals

params.name: Signal
params.description: Reference to Signal object that listener is currently bound to.

params.name: listener
params.description: Handler function bound to the signal.

params.name: isOnce
params.description: If binding should be executed just once.

params.name: listenerContext
params.description: Context on which listener will be executed (object that should represent the `this` variable inside listener function).

params.name: priority
params.description: The priority level of the event listener. (default = 0).

Kiwi.Stage.name: Kiwi.Stage
Kiwi.Stage.description:
Each game contains a single Stage which controls the creation and management of main domElements required for a Kiwi game to work. 
Such as the Canvas and the rendering contexts, as well as the width/height of the game and the position it should be on the screen.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this Stage belongs to.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the kiwi game.

params.name: width
params.description: The initial width of the game.

params.name: height
params.description: The initial heihgt of the game.

params.name: scaleType
params.description: The scale method that should be used for the game.

Kiwi.State.name: Kiwi.State
Kiwi.State.description:
A State in Kiwi.JS is the main class that developers use when wanting to create a Game. 
States in Kiwi are used keep different sections of a game seperated. So a single game maybe comprised of many different States. 
Such as one for the menu, in-game, leaderboard, e.t.c.
There can only ever be a single State active at a given time.

params.name: name
params.description: Name of this State. Should be unique to differentiate itself from other States.

Kiwi.StateConfig.name: Kiwi.StateConfig
Kiwi.StateConfig.description: A lightweight object that contains values relating to the configuration of a State in a Kiwi Game.

params.name: parent
params.description: The State that this configuration object belongs to.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the state which was created.

Kiwi.StateManager.name: Kiwi.StateManager
Kiwi.StateManager.description:
The State Manager handles the starting, parsing, looping and swapping of game States within a Kiwi Game
There is only ever one State Manager per game, but a single Game can contain multiple States.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this statemanager belongs to.

Kiwi.Files.DataLibrary.name: Kiwi.Files.DataLibrary
Kiwi.Files.DataLibrary.description: Holds a reference to all of the data Files (json, xml, e.t.c) that are accessible on the State that this DataLibrary is on.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this DataLibrary belongs to.

Kiwi.Files.File.name: Kiwi.Files.File
Kiwi.Files.File.description:
Handles the loading of an external data file via a tag loader OR xhr + arraybuffer, and optionally saves to the file store.
Also can contain information about the file (like file size, last modified, e.t.c.) either after it has been loaded 
OR if you use the 'getFileDetails' method and the properties will then be set.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this file belongs to.

params.name: dataType
params.description: The type of file that is being loaded. For this you can use the STATIC properties that are located on this class for quick code completion.

params.name: path
params.description: The location of the file that is to be loaded.

params.name: name
params.description: A name for the file. If no name is specified then the files name will be used.

params.name: saveToFileStore
params.description: If the file should be saved on the file store or not.

params.name: storeAsGlobal
params.description: If this file should be stored as a global file, or if it should be destroyed when this state gets switched out.

Kiwi.Files.FileStore.name: Kiwi.Files.FileStore
Kiwi.Files.FileStore.description: Holds all of the Files (regardless of the file type) that have been loaded throughout a game/are accessable at a particular point in time. Contains methods for dealing with files. Note: Each time the state is switched the file store will remove all references to files that have not been flagged as global.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this FileStore belongs to.

Kiwi.Files.Loader.name: Kiwi.Files.Loader
Kiwi.Files.Loader.description: Used for the loading of files and game assets. This usually happens when a State is at the 'loading' stage (executing the 'preload' method).

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this loader belongs to.

Kiwi.GameObjects.Tilemap.TileMap.name: Kiwi.GameObjects.Tilemap.TileMap
Kiwi.GameObjects.Tilemap.TileMap.description:
A TileMap handles the creation of TileMapLayers and the TileTypes that they use.
Since a TileMap isn't a Entity itself you cannot add it to the Stage inorder to render that it manages, 
Instead you have to add each layer lies within it. This way you can have other GameObjects behind/in-front of layers.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this Tilemap is on.

params.name: tileMapDataKey
params.description: The Data key for the JSON you would like to use.

params.name: atlas
params.description: The texture atlas that you would like the tilemap layers to use.

params.name: startingCell
params.description: The number for the initial cell that the first TileType should use. See 'createFromFileStore' for more information.

Kiwi.GameObjects.Tilemap.TileMapLayer.name: Kiwi.GameObjects.Tilemap.TileMapLayer
Kiwi.GameObjects.Tilemap.TileMapLayer.description:
GameObject that contains the information held for a single Layer of Tiles, along with methods to handle the rendering of those Tiles. 
A TileMapLayer should not be directly created, but instead should be created through a TileMap object instead.

params.name: tilemap
params.description: The TileMap that this layer belongs to.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of this TileMapLayer.

params.name: atlas
params.description: The texture atlas that should be used when rendering this TileMapLayer onscreen.

params.name: data
params.description: The information about the tiles.

params.name: tw
params.description: The width of a single tile in pixels. Usually the same as the TileMap unless told otherwise.

params.name: th
params.description: The height of a single tile in pixels. Usually the same as the TileMap unless told otherwise.

params.name: x
params.description: The x coordinate of the tilemap in pixels.

params.name: y
params.description: The y coordinate of the tilemap in pixels.

params.name: w
params.description: The width of the whole tilemap in tiles. Usually the same as the TileMap unless told otherwise.

params.name: h
params.description: The height of the whole tilemap in tiles. Usually the same as the TileMap unless told otherwise.

Kiwi.GameObjects.Tilemap.TileType.name: Kiwi.GameObjects.Tilemap.TileType
Kiwi.GameObjects.Tilemap.TileType.description:
Define's the properties of a single Type of Tile for a TileMap. This class should not be directly instanted, 
but instead when wanting to create new TileType's you should use the 'createdTileType' methods on a TileMap object.

params.name: tilemap
params.description: The TileMap that this TileType is a part of.

params.name: index
params.description: The index of this TileType, which Tiles use when wanting to use this TileType.

params.name: cellIndex
params.description: The cell number to use when rendering this Type of Tile.

Kiwi.GameObjects.Sprite.name: Kiwi.GameObjects.Sprite
Kiwi.GameObjects.Sprite.description: A Sprite is a general purpose GameObject that contains majority of the functionality that is needed/would be wanted and as such should be used only when you are wanting a GameObject with a lot of interaction. When creating a Sprite you pass to it as TextureAtlas (for the image you want to render), now if that Texture Atlas isn't a SINGLE_IMAGE then the Sprite will have an AnimationManager Component to handle any SpriteSheet animations you need.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this sprite belongs to

params.name: atlas
params.description: The texture you want to apply to this entity

params.name: x
params.description: The sprites initial coordinates on the x axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The sprites initial coordinates on the y axis.

params.name: enableInput
params.description: If the input component should be enabled or not.

Kiwi.GameObjects.StaticImage.name: Kiwi.GameObjects.StaticImage
Kiwi.GameObjects.StaticImage.description: A light weight game object for displaying static images that would have little or no interaction with other GameObjects. An Example of this would be a background image. Note: Since a StaticImage is lightweight it doesn't have any AnimationManager to handle the switching of cells (If you were using a SpriteSheet/TextureAtlas). In order to switch cells you can change the value of the cellIndex property.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this static image belongs to

params.name: atlas
params.description: The texture atlas to use as the image.

params.name: x
params.description: Its coordinates on the x axis

params.name: y
params.description: The coordinates on the y axis

Kiwi.GameObjects.Textfield.name: Kiwi.GameObjects.Textfield
Kiwi.GameObjects.Textfield.description: Textfield is a GameObject that is used when you are wanting to render text onto the current State. The Textfield is not designed to have any interaction with other GameObjects and as such it does not have many (if any) components or even a width/height.

params.name: state
params.description: The state that this Textfield belongs to

params.name: text
params.description: The text that is contained within this textfield.

params.name: x
params.description: The new x coordinate from the Position component

params.name: y
params.description: The new y coordinate from the Position component

params.name: color
params.description: The color of the text.

params.name: size
params.description: The size of the text in pixels.

params.name: weight
params.description: The weight of the text.

params.name: fontFamily
params.description: The font family that is to be used when rendering.

Kiwi.Geom.AABB.name: Kiwi.Geom.AABB
Kiwi.Geom.AABB.description: An object representation of an axis-aligned bounding box.

Kiwi.Geom.Circle.name: Kiwi.Geom.Circle
Kiwi.Geom.Circle.description:
A Circle object is an area defined by its position, 
as indicated by its center point (x,y) and diameter.

params.name: [x
params.description: = 0]  The x coordinate of the center of the circle.

params.name: [y
params.description: = 0]  The y coordinate of the center of the circle.

params.name: [diameter
params.description: = 0]  The diameter of the circle.

Kiwi.Geom.Intersect.name: Kiwi.Geom.Intersect
Kiwi.Geom.Intersect.description: Contains a collection of STATIC methods to help determine and return intersection between geometric objects.

Kiwi.Geom.IntersectResult.name: Kiwi.Geom.IntersectResult
Kiwi.Geom.IntersectResult.description:
A Lightweight object to hold the results of an Intersection. 
Used in combination with the STATIC methods on the Intersect class.

Kiwi.Geom.Line.name: Kiwi.Geom.Line
Kiwi.Geom.Line.description:
A Kiwi Line object has two meanings depending on the situation you need. 
Either an infinte line through space (this is the usual meaning of a Line) 
OR it can be a Line Segment which just exists between the TWO points you specify.

params.name: [x1
params.description: = 0]  x1 x component of first point.

params.name: [y1
params.description: = 0] y1 y component of first point.

params.name: [x2
params.description: = 0] x2 x component of second point.

params.name: [y2
params.description: = 0] y2 y component of second point.

Kiwi.Geom.Matrix.name: Kiwi.Geom.Matrix
Kiwi.Geom.Matrix.description:
Represents a 2d transformation matrix. This can be used to map points between different coordinate spaces. Matrices are used
by Transform objects to represent translation, scale and rotation transformations, and to determine where objects are in world space or camera space.
Objects such as entities and groups may be nested, and their associated transforms may represent how they are scaled, translated and rotated relative to a parent
transform.
By concatenating an object's transformation matrix with it's ancestors matrices, it is possible to determine the absolute position of the object in world space.
See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformation_matrix#Examples_in_2D_graphics for an in depth discussion of 2d tranformation matrices.

params.name: [a
params.description: = 1]   position 0,0 of the matrix, affects scaling and rotation.

params.name: [b
params.description: = 0]   position 0,1 of the matrix, affects scaling and rotation.

params.name: [c
params.description: = 0]   position 1,0 of the matrix, affects scaling and rotation.

params.name: [d
params.description: = 1]   position 1,1 of the matrix, affects scaling and rotation.

params.name: [tx
params.description: = 0]   position 2,0 of the matrix, affects translation on x axis.

params.name: [ty
params.description: = 0]   position 2,1 of the matrix, affects translation on y axis.

Kiwi.Geom.Point.name: Kiwi.Geom.Point
Kiwi.Geom.Point.description: Represents a location in a two-dimensional coordinate system, where x represents the horizontal axis and y represents the vertical axis.

params.name: x
params.description: x One-liner. Default is ?.

params.name: y
params.description: y One-liner. Default is ?.

Kiwi.Geom.Ray.name: Kiwi.Geom.Ray
Kiwi.Geom.Ray.description: Represents a halfline. The ray starts at the first point and extends infinitely in the direction of the second.

Kiwi.Geom.Rectangle.name: Kiwi.Geom.Rectangle
Kiwi.Geom.Rectangle.description: An area defined by its position, as indicated by its top-left corner (x,y) and width and height

params.name: [x
params.description: = 0]  The x coordinate of the top-left corner of the rectangle.

params.name: [y
params.description: = 0]  The y coordinate of the top-left corner of the rectangle.

params.name: [width
params.description: = 0]  width The width of the rectangle in pixels.

params.name: [height
params.description: = 0]  height The height of the rectangle in pixels.

Kiwi.Geom.Transform.name: Kiwi.Geom.Transform
Kiwi.Geom.Transform.description:
Represents position, scale, rotation and rotationPoint of an Entity.
- Values can be transformed with a 3x3 affine transformation matrix, which each transform is assigned.
- A tranform can be assigned a parent, which may in turn have it's own parent, thereby creating a tranform inheritence heirarchy
- A concatenated transformation matrix, representing the combined matrices of the transform and its ancestors.

params.name: x
params.description: x. X position of the transform.

params.name: y
params.description: y. Y position of the transform.

params.name: scaleX
params.description: scaleX. X scaling of the transform.

params.name: scaleY
params.description: scaleY. Y scaling of the transform.

params.name: rotation
params.description: rotation. Rotation of the transform in radians.

params.name: rotX
params.description: rotX. rotationPoint offset on X axis.

params.name: rotY
params.description: rotY. rotationPoint offset on Y axis.

Kiwi.Geom.Vector2.name: Kiwi.Geom.Vector2
Kiwi.Geom.Vector2.description: A two dimensional vector object for storing and manipulating x and y vector components.

params.name: x
params.description: The x component of the vector.

params.name: y
params.description: The y component of the vector.

Kiwi.HUD.HUDComponents.Counter.name: Kiwi.HUD.HUDComponents.Counter
Kiwi.HUD.HUDComponents.Counter.description:
The Counter component handles a incrementation/decrementation of a singular numeric value. 
You can also specifiy maximum/minimum values that the numeric value has be within but by default there is no max/min.

params.name: owner
params.description: The object that this Component belongs to.

params.name: current
params.description: The current value.

params.name: max
params.description: The maximum value it can be. Default is null which means no maximum.

params.name: min
params.description: The minimum value that the current can be. Default is null which means no minium.

Kiwi.HUD.HUDComponents.Time.name: Kiwi.HUD.HUDComponents.Time
Kiwi.HUD.HUDComponents.Time.description:
A Component to manage and display a Time in a particular format.
The Time Component creates a new clock on the Time Manager and it use's that clock to keep track of the time.
When you create a new Time Component you can specify a format that you want the time to display in, which is a string based on keywords.
Current supported keywords for the format are:
 's' = 'seconds'
 'm' = 'minutes'
 'ms' = milliseconds'
 'ss' = 'seconds with leading zero'
 'mm' = 'minutes with leading zero'

params.name: owner
params.description: The object that this component belongs to.

params.name: format
params.description: The format that the time is to be displayed in. Leave blank for the default time.

Kiwi.HUD.HUDComponents.WidgetInput.name: Kiwi.HUD.HUDComponents.WidgetInput
Kiwi.HUD.HUDComponents.WidgetInput.description:
The WidgetInput Component handles the input events that you may want to listen to on a widget.
This Component is essentually another version of the normal Input Component but instead of for GameObjects this is for HUDWidgets.

params.name: owner
params.description: The object that this WidgetInput belongs to.

params.name: container
params.description: The HTMLElement that the events will occur on/to.

Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Bar.name: Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Bar
Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Bar.description:
Used for displaying of information in a bar like of format. Example: Amount of health remaining for a character.
This class creates a 'innerbar' div inside of its main container which you can apply styles to.
You can control the minimum/maximum and current values of the bar through the Counter widget.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this bar belongs to.

params.name: current
params.description: The current value of the bar.

params.name: max
params.description: The maximum value that there can be.

params.name: x
params.description: The coordinates of this widget on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The cooridnates of this widget on the y-axis.

params.name: width
params.description: The width of the widget. Defaults to 120.

params.name: height
params.description: The height of the widget. Defaults to 20.

params.name: color
params.description: The default color of the inner bar. Defaults to #000 (black).

Kiwi.HUD.Widget.BasicScore.name: Kiwi.HUD.Widget.BasicScore
Kiwi.HUD.Widget.BasicScore.description:
A subclass of textfield that is primarily used to keep track of a score.
The score can be accessed via the counter component.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this BasicScore belongs to.

params.name: x
params.description: The cooridnates of the game on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The cooridnates of the game on the y-axis.

params.name: initial
params.description: The initial score to start off at.

Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Button.name: Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Button
Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Button.description: A subclass of the TextField that has its own input component so that you can listen for mouse events on this widget.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this belongs to.

params.name: text
params.description: The text that you want to display inside the button.

params.name: x
params.description: The x-coordnates of this Widget.

params.name: y
params.description: The y-coordinates of this Widget.

Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Icon.name: Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Icon
Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Icon.description:
Used to display a cell from a TextureAtlas in the HUD. This could be used for portraits of the character, e.t.c.
You can change the current cell that is being used in the TextureAtlas by modifing the cellIndex property.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this icon belongs to.

params.name: atlas
params.description: The image that you would like displayed.

params.name: x
params.description: The coordinate of the icon on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The coordinate of the icon on the y-axis.

Kiwi.HUD.Widget.IconBar.name: Kiwi.HUD.Widget.IconBar
Kiwi.HUD.Widget.IconBar.description:
The IconBar used to display a series of icons which represent a number of 'something' the user may have. 
Example: If you had a shooter style game you might want to display the amount of 'ammo' left in the gun using a series of bullet icons. You could then use this IconBar to display that series.
The amount is based of a counter components current value, so you can set a maximum and minimum number of images to be displayed.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this icon bar belongs to.

params.name: atlas
params.description: The texture atlas that the icons will have.

params.name: current
params.description: The current amount of icons in the bar.

params.name: max
params.description: The maximum number of icons.

params.name: x
params.description: The x coordinates of the first icon.

params.name: y
params.description: The y coordinates of the last icon.

Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Menu.name: Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Menu
Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Menu.description:
A Widget for that is used for the management/displaying of a Menu. 
This class is primarily used as a manager of MenuItems, so on this class you can create/add MenuItems
and styles that you want applyed to all MenuItems.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this Menu belongs to.

params.name: x
params.description: Its position on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: Its position on the y -axis.

Kiwi.HUD.Widget.MenuItem.name: Kiwi.HUD.Widget.MenuItem
Kiwi.HUD.Widget.MenuItem.description:
A MenuItem extends the Button Widget and is typically contained inside of a Menu Widget. 
Since a MenuItem extends the Button Widget you can access the Input Component that it has to listen to mouse events.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this MenuItem belongs to.

params.name: text
params.description: The text that is to be inside the menuitem.

params.name: x
params.description: The position of this menu item on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The position of this menu item on the y-axis.

Kiwi.HUD.Widget.TextField.name: Kiwi.HUD.Widget.TextField
Kiwi.HUD.Widget.TextField.description:
A Widget that is used for the displaying of text on the HUD. 
Foreach TextField you can add some prefix/suffix text, which is more useful on classes extending this one.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this textfield belongs to.

params.name: text
params.description: The text on this textfield.

params.name: x
params.description: The x coordinates

params.name: y
params.description: The y coordinates

Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Time.name: Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Time
Kiwi.HUD.Widget.Time.description:
A subclass of TextField which manages the displaying of a Time/Timer by creating a new clock on the Time Manager.
The time is managed by a Time Component which contains a format property that handles how the time should be formatted.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this object belongs to.

params.name: format
params.description: The format that you want the time to be displayed in. Leave it empty to display as normal.

params.name: x
params.description: The position of this text on the field.

params.name: y
params.description: The position of this text on the field.

Kiwi.HUD.HUDDisplay.name: Kiwi.HUD.HUDDisplay
Kiwi.HUD.HUDDisplay.description:
A HUDDisplay is a container for which you can add/removes widget on, and is more used to manage the widgets that are being displayed on it.
A HUDDisplay is created through a games HUDManager and is NOT directly instantiated.
Each game can contain multiple HUDDisplay's and each HUDDisplay can contain multiple HUDWidgets.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this HUD Display belongs to.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of this display.

Kiwi.HUD.HUDManager.name: Kiwi.HUD.HUDManager
Kiwi.HUD.HUDManager.description:
This class manages all of the various HUDDisplays that are currently used on this Managers game.
Using this class you can create/add and remove HUDDisplays from this game,
change the HUDDisplay that is currently being display (also known as the currentHUD) and show/hide the currentHUD.
Each HUDManager also has at least one HUDDisplay which is called the 'defaultHUD' you cannot remove,
but you can reassign the defaultHUD to be a different HUDDisplay if you want.

params.name: game
params.description: game

Kiwi.HUD.HUDWidget.name: Kiwi.HUD.HUDWidget
Kiwi.HUD.HUDWidget.description:
The HUDWidget is an abstract class containing the fundamental properties and methods that every HUDWidget needs to have.
This class is designed to be extended from and thus objects should not directly instantiate it.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this HUDWidget belongs to.

params.name: name
params.description: Name of the type of HUDWidget.

params.name: x
params.description: The coordinates of this HUDWidget on the x-axis.

params.name: y
params.description: The coordinates of this HUDWidget on the y-axis.

Kiwi.Input.Finger.name: Kiwi.Input.Finger
Kiwi.Input.Finger.description: Used with the Touch manager class, this object holds information about a single touch point/locaton (or you know a finger). By default a Finger has a diameter of 44 pixels (random average size of a finger) which can be used for collision/overlap detection. That value can be modified. Note: A Finger is only active whilst the user is 'pressing' down on stage.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this finger belongs to.

Kiwi.Input.InputManager.name: Kiwi.Input.InputManager
Kiwi.Input.InputManager.description:
Handles the initialization and management of the various ways a user can interact with the device/game,
whether this is through a Keyboard and Mouse or by a Touch. Also contains some of the general callbacks that are 'global' between both Desktop and Mobile based devices.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this object belongs to.

Kiwi.Input.Key.name: Kiwi.Input.Key
Kiwi.Input.Key.description: A compact object that holds the most important details about a Keyboard Event response.

params.name: manager
params.description: The keyboard manager that this key belongs to.

params.name: keycode
params.description: The keycode that this key is.

params.name: event
params.description: The keyboard event (if there was one) when this was created.

Kiwi.Input.Keyboard.name: Kiwi.Input.Keyboard
Kiwi.Input.Keyboard.description: Handles and Manages the dispatching of keyboard events. When the user press's a button a new Key object is created.

Kiwi.Input.Keycodes.name: Kiwi.Input.Keycodes
Kiwi.Input.Keycodes.description: A Static class which has a property associated with all all of the character codes on a typical keyboard. While you don't need this class for your game to work, it is quite handy to use as it can speed up the development process.

Kiwi.Input.Mouse.name: Kiwi.Input.Mouse
Kiwi.Input.Mouse.description: Handles the dispatching/management of Mouse Events on a game. When this class is instantiated a MouseCursor object is also created (on this object) which holds the information that is unique to the mouse cursor, although majority of that information is still accessible inside this object.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this mouse manager belongs to.

Kiwi.Input.MouseCursor.name: Kiwi.Input.MouseCursor
Kiwi.Input.MouseCursor.description: Holds the information about a Mouse Cursor. Such as the position of the cursor, the mouse wheels delta, the button that was used, e.t.c. Note: A mouse cursor is always active.

Kiwi.Input.Pointer.name: Kiwi.Input.Pointer
Kiwi.Input.Pointer.description: Is a generic class that holds the properties/methods that are common across various different methods of inputs from the user, mainly between Touch and Mouse based events. This abstract class and such it is suppose to be extended from for individual implementations.

Kiwi.Input.Touch.name: Kiwi.Input.Touch
Kiwi.Input.Touch.description: Handles the dispatching and management of touch based events for the game. When the Touch manager is created TEN finger objects are created and used when the user interacts with the screen. Those finger are what you can use to create games that make the most out of multitouch events.

params.name: game
params.description: the game that this touch manager belongs to.

Kiwi.Renderers.Renderer.name: Kiwi.Renderers.Renderer
Kiwi.Renderers.Renderer.description: Base class for WebGL Renderers. Not for instantiation.

Kiwi.Renderers.TextureAtlasRenderer.name: Kiwi.Renderers.TextureAtlasRenderer
Kiwi.Renderers.TextureAtlasRenderer.description: The Renderer object for rendering Texture Atlases

Kiwi.Shaders.ShaderPair.name: Kiwi.Shaders.ShaderPair
Kiwi.Shaders.ShaderPair.description: Base class for shader pairs which encapsulate a GLSL vertex and fragment shader

Kiwi.Shaders.TextureAtlasShader.name: Kiwi.Shaders.TextureAtlasShader
Kiwi.Shaders.TextureAtlasShader.description: Shader wrapper for rendering Texture Atlases

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this canvas renderer belongs to.

Kiwi.Renderers.GLBlendMode.name: Kiwi.Renderers.GLBlendMode
Kiwi.Renderers.GLBlendMode.description: The Blend Mode object for recording and applying GL blend functions on a renderer.

Kiwi.Renderers.GLElementArrayBuffer.name: Kiwi.Renderers.GLElementArrayBuffer
Kiwi.Renderers.GLElementArrayBuffer.description: Encapsulates a WebGL E;ement Array Buffer

Kiwi.Renderers.GLRenderManager.name: Kiwi.Renderers.GLRenderManager
Kiwi.Renderers.GLRenderManager.description:
Manages all rendering using WebGL. Requires the inclusion of gl-matrix.js / g-matrix.min.js -  https://github.com/toji/gl-matrix
Directly manages renderer objects, including factory methods for their creation. 
Creates manager objects for shaders and textures.
Manages gl state at game initialisation, at state start and end, and per frame.
Runs the recursive scene graph rendering sequence every frame.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this renderer belongs to.

Kiwi.Shaders.ShaderManager.name: Kiwi.Shaders.ShaderManager
Kiwi.Shaders.ShaderManager.description:
Manages all WebGL Shaders. Maintains a list of ShaderPairs 
 
Provides an interface for using a specific ShaderPair, adding new ShaderPairs, and requesting a reference to a ShaderPair instance.
Renderes use shaderPairs to draw. Multiple renderers may use the same compiled shader program.
This Manager ensures only one compiled instance of each program is created

Kiwi.Renderers.GLTextureManager.name: Kiwi.Renderers.GLTextureManager
Kiwi.Renderers.GLTextureManager.description: Manages GL Texture objects, including creation, uploading, destruction and memory management

Kiwi.Sound.Audio.name: Kiwi.Sound.Audio
Kiwi.Sound.Audio.description:
The Audio Object contains the functionality for playing a singular sound in a Kiwi Game. 
The Audio can contain Audio Sprites which is a nice way to play audio on mobile devices. 
Audio Objects do not 'die' when game states are switched or changed.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this piece of audio belongs to.

params.name: key
params.description: The key to which which piece of audio should be loaded from the AudioLibrary.

params.name: volume
params.description: A number between 0 (silence) and 1 (loud).

params.name: loop
params.description: If the audio should loop when it is finished or just stop.

Kiwi.Sound.AudioLibrary.name: Kiwi.Sound.AudioLibrary
Kiwi.Sound.AudioLibrary.description: Holds a reference to all of the Audio Files (mp3, ogg, e.t.c) that are accessible on the State that this AudioLibrary is on.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this audio library is a member of.

Kiwi.Sound.AudioManager.name: Kiwi.Sound.AudioManager
Kiwi.Sound.AudioManager.description:
Manages the initialisation of assets necessary when dealing with audio in the game, either through Audio Tags or the Web Audio API. 
Also provides global sound controls that will be applyed to all Audio objects at the same time, within the Game this manager is a part of.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this audio manager belongs to.

Kiwi.System.Bootstrap.name: Kiwi.System.Bootstrap
Kiwi.System.Bootstrap.description: DOM Boot and Ready functions (based on those used by jQuery)

Kiwi.System.Device.name: Kiwi.System.Device
Kiwi.System.Device.description:
Detects device support capabilities. Using some elements from System.js by MrDoob and Modernizr
https://github.com/Modernizr/Modernizr/blob/master/feature-detects/audio.js
Kiwi.System.Device.author: Modernizr team

Kiwi.Textures.SingleImage.name: Kiwi.Textures.SingleImage
Kiwi.Textures.SingleImage.description: A special type of TextureAtlas that is used when the user has loaded a single image. This type of TextureAtlas contains only one cell which is generally the whole width/height of the image and starts at the coordinates 0/0. A SingleImage has a space to store sequences but this will not be used.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the single image

params.name: image
params.description: the image that is being used.

params.name: width
params.description: the width of the image

params.name: height
params.description: the height of the image

params.name: offsetX
params.description: the offset of the image on the x axis. Useful if the image has a border that you don't want to show.

params.name: offsetY
params.description: the offset of the image of the y axis. Useful if the image has a border that you don't want to show.

Kiwi.Textures.SpriteSheet.name: Kiwi.Textures.SpriteSheet
Kiwi.Textures.SpriteSheet.description: A special type of TextureAtlas that is created when loading in images that are design to be SpriteSheets. A SpriteSheet will generally contain multiple cells and can also contain sequences which are then automatically added as Animations when this texture is used on a Sprite.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the spritesheet.

params.name: texture
params.description: The image that is being used for the spritesheet.

params.name: cellWidth
params.description: The width of a single cell.

params.name: cellHeight
params.description: The height of a single cell.

params.name: numCells
params.description: The number of cells in total.

params.name: rows
params.description: The number of cells that make up a row.

params.name: cols
params.description: The number of cells that make up a column.

params.name: sheetOffsetX
params.description: The offset of the whole sheet on the x axis. Useful if the image has a border you don't want to show.

params.name: sheetOffsetY
params.description: The offset of the whole sheet on the y axis. Useful if the image has a border you don't want to show.

params.name: cellOffsetX
params.description: An offset between cells on the x axis. Useful if there is a border between cells which is not to be shown.

params.name: cellOffsetY
params.description: An offset between cells on the y axis. Useful if there is a border between cells which is not to be shown.

Kiwi.Textures.TextureAtlas.name: Kiwi.Textures.TextureAtlas
Kiwi.Textures.TextureAtlas.description: A TextureAtlas is the base class that is created for each image that is loaded through Kiwi. Each TextureAtlas contains a name (the same as the key that the user chose when loading the image in),the HTMLImageElement that it is for and a number of cells.

params.name: name
params.description: Name of the texture atlas. This is usually defined by the developer when loading the assets.

params.name: type
params.description: The type of texture atlas that this is. There are currently only three types.

params.name: cells
params.description: The cells that are within this image..

params.name: image
params.description: The image that the texture atlas is using.

params.name: sequences
params.description: Any sequences of cells for this texture atlas. Used for animation.

Kiwi.Textures.TextureLibrary.name: Kiwi.Textures.TextureLibrary
Kiwi.Textures.TextureLibrary.description: Holds a reference to all of the image files (jpg, png, e.t.c) that are accessible on the State this TextureLibrary is on.

params.name: game
params.description: The game that this texture library belongs to.

Kiwi.Time.Clock.name: Kiwi.Time.Clock
Kiwi.Time.Clock.description:
The Clock class offers a way of tracking time within a game. When creating a new Clock you should NOT directly instantiate this class but instead use the addClock method on a ClockManager.
- The MasterClock is a property of the Kiwi.Time.Manager class and tracks real world time in milliseconds elapsed since the application started. This happens automatically and there is no need to do anything to set this up.
- An instance of a clock is used to track time in arbitrary units (milliseconds by default)
- A clock can be started, paused, unpaused and stopped. Once stopped, re-starting the clock again will reset it.
- Any number of timers can be attached to a clock. See the Kiwi.Time.Timer class for timer details.
- If the clock is paused, any timers attached to the clock will take this into account and not continue to fire events until the clock is unpaused.
(Note that this is not the same as pausing timers, which can be done manually and needs to be undone manually.)

params.name: manager
params.description: The ClockManager that this clock belongs to. .

params.name: master
params.description: The MasterClock that it is getting the time in relation to.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the clock.

params.name: units
params.description: The units that this clock is to operate in.

Kiwi.Time.ClockManager.name: Kiwi.Time.ClockManager
Kiwi.Time.ClockManager.description: Handles the generation and tracking of Clocks and Time related applications for a single game.

Kiwi.Time.MasterClock.name: Kiwi.Time.MasterClock
Kiwi.Time.MasterClock.description:
The MasterClock tracks time elapsed since the application started.
Each ClockManager has only one MasterClock which is automatically generated when the game initially booted.
You should not access it directly, use the Clock and Timer classes instead.

Kiwi.Time.Timer.name: Kiwi.Time.Timer
Kiwi.Time.Timer.description:
The Timer class hooks into a game Clock and allows you run code at a specified point in game time.
Use the start() method to start a timer. Add TimerEvents to set-up code to be run on the timer interval.
Timer objects can run once or repeat at specified intervals to execute code on a schedule.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the timer.

params.name: clock
params.description: The game clock instance this Timer is based on.

params.name: delay
params.description: The number of clock units to wait between firing events.

params.name: repeatCount
params.description: The number of times to repeat the timer before it is expired. If you don't want it to ever expire, set a value of -1.

Kiwi.Time.TimerEvent.name: Kiwi.Time.TimerEvent
Kiwi.Time.TimerEvent.description: A TimerEvent hooks into a Timer and is an object that is generated when you are wanting to executed a callback at a specific point in time.

params.name: type
params.description: The type of TimerEvent that this is.

params.name: callback
params.description: The method that is to be executed when the event occurs.

params.name: context
params.description: The context that the callback is to be called in.

Kiwi.Utils.Canvas.name: Kiwi.Utils.Canvas
Kiwi.Utils.Canvas.description: Creates and the manages a Canvas DOMElement.

params.name: width
params.description: The width of the canvas.

params.name: height
params.description: The height of the canvas.

params.name: visible
params.description: If the canvas is visible or not.

params.name: offScreen
params.description: If the canvas is designed to be offscreen or not.

Kiwi.Utils.Common.name: Kiwi.Utils.Common
Kiwi.Utils.Common.description:
Methods to assist in working with Structs.
A lot of the functions in this class are Copyright 2012 Mauricio Santos and used with permission.
His work is licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License")
Kiwi.Utils.Common.author: Mauricio Santos

Kiwi.Utils.GameMath.name: Kiwi.Utils.GameMath
Kiwi.Utils.GameMath.description:
Adds a set of extra Math functions and extends a few commonly used ones.
Includes some methods written by Dylan Engelman.
Kiwi.Utils.GameMath.author: Dylan Engelman

Kiwi.Utils.RandomDataGenerator.name: Kiwi.Utils.RandomDataGenerator
Kiwi.Utils.RandomDataGenerator.description:
Manages the creation of unique internal game IDs.
Based on Nonsense by Josh Faul https://github.com/jocafa/Nonsense
Random number generator from http://baagoe.org/en/wiki/Better_random_numbers_for_javascript
Kiwi.Utils.RandomDataGenerator.author: Josh Faul

Kiwi.Utils.RequestAnimationFrame.name: Kiwi.Utils.RequestAnimationFrame
Kiwi.Utils.RequestAnimationFrame.description: Abstracts away the use of RAF or setTimeout for the core game update loop. The callback can be re-mapped on the fly.

Kiwi.Utils.Version.name: Kiwi.Utils.Version
Kiwi.Utils.Version.description: Deals with parsing and comparing semver style version numbers

Kiwi.GameManager.name: Kiwi.GameManager
Kiwi.GameManager.description: The GameManager is used to maintain mulitple instances of Kiwi games within a single document.

classitems.description: The AnimationManager that this animation is a child of.

classitems.description: The name of this animation.
classitems.name: name

classitems.description: The sequence on the texture atlas that this animation is based off.
classitems.name: _sequence

classitems.description: If this animation should loop or not.
classitems.name: _loop

classitems.description: If once the animation reaches the end, it should start again from the first cell in the sequence or not.
classitems.name: loop

classitems.description:
The current frame index that the animation is currently upto.
Note: A frame index is the index of a particular cell in the Sequence.
classitems.name: _frameIndex

classitems.description:
The current frame index that the animation is currently upto.
Note: A frame index is the index of a particular cell in the Sequence.
classitems.name: frameIndex

classitems.description: Returns the current cell that the animation is up to. This is READ ONLY.
classitems.name: currentCell

classitems.description: How fast the transition is between cells. Perhaps change to frames per second to reflect actual game speed?
classitems.name: _speed

classitems.description: How long the each cell should stay on screen for. In seconds.
classitems.name: speed

classitems.description: The clock that is to be used to calculate the animations.
classitems.name: _clock

classitems.description: The starting time of the animation from when it was played. Internal use only.
